snippet: Despite all the spending by both sides, the long presidential campaign didn’t seem to leave some voters with a clearer view of the candidates.
abstract: Voters nationwide express relief that the strident and polarizing campaign has come to an end; record amounts of spending on radio and television advertisements, direct mail, phone calls and a deluge of other political solicitations left many voters exhausted and disgusted with the political process.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Lizette Alvarez from Miami; Jess Bidgood from Pembroke, N.H.; Monica Davey from Cincinnati; Jack Healy from Denver; Norimitsu Onishi from San Francisco; Rebecca Raney from Glendora, Calif.; Campbell Robertson from Tampa, Fla.; and Kim Severson from Atlanta.

lead_paragraph: Despite all the spending by both sides, the long presidential campaign didn’t seem to leave some voters with a clearer view of the candidates.

headline.seo: Voters Express Relief and Lingering Confusion as Campaign Ends
headline.main: The Most Sought-After Voters Were No Longer Flattered by the Attention
headline.print_headline: The Most Sought-After Voters Were No Longer Flattered by the Attention
